Her hand finally locates the jar labelled, "Sweet Pea." The Evil Scientist calls from another room:
Sally?
Still choking, hardly able even to squeak out an answer, struggles to open the Sweet Pea jar.
Where's my soup?
Sally finally gets the jar open.  As fast as she can, she it into the soup and hovers above the pot.  In a moment, Sweet Pea takes effect and Sally's strength begins to ret
(gasps) Coming...
Good.  I'm hungry.
Still a bit shaky, Sally reaches for one more jar.  The l this one reads, "Worm's Wart."
(hoarsely) A handful of Worm's Wart just for distraction.  It'll throw him off the trail for sure...
She drops in some Worm's Wart, stirs the soup, then ladle bowlful.

The Evil Scientist is at his lab table, peering into a mi and thinking -- which, for him, involves lifting off the his skull and tickling and scrambling the brains inside. Sally carries in a tray holding his bowl of soup.
Lunch.
The scientist impatiently gestures her over.  He replaces of his skull...
Excellent.  Over here.  Over here.  Set it down.
She gingerly sets the tray in front of him. The scientist inhales a deep sniff of the steam curling o soup.
Ah...  What's that?...  Worm's Wart!
He glances suspiciously at Sally.
What trail are you trying to throw me off now?
(stammers; feigns innocence) Nothing.  W-w-what are you talking about?
The scientist pushes the bowl of soup toward Sally.
Taste it.
But why?  It's your lunch. There isn't much there in the first place.
Taste it.
No.
Why not?
I'm not hungry. (acts all hurt) What's wrong?  I spent all morning on that soup.  I thought you liked Worm's Wart.
There's nothing more suspicious than Worm's Wart -- it distracts one from every other taste and smell.
He dips a spoon into the soup then holds it up to Sally.
Until you taste it, I won't eat a bite.
Sally crumples.
But I have to go out. Something's happening out there.
Whatever it is, it's none of your concern.
He waves the spoon at her.
Eat.
She keeps her lips closed tight.
(lapses into self-pity mode) Then we'll both starve...  An old man like me, who hardly has strength as it is -- me, without whom... me, your own father...
Can't you make other creations?
I could.  Of course I could. But no one would be like you... (pours it on again) I'll never understand how you can be so cold-hearted, how you can treat me this way, discarding me like--
It works.  He wears Sally down:
(interrupts) All right...  All right... I'll eat it.
She closes her eyes and sips the soup off the spoon.

The Mayor lies sprawled on top of his hearse, staring up sky for ideas.  He's exhausted, as are the assembled citi Halloweenland, exhausted from exhausting their alternativ it comes to seeking Jack. The Mayor lifts his heavy head and feebly asks:
Did anybody think to dredge the lake?
A recumbent corpse sits up and nods:
This morning.
The corpse flops down again. The mayor lets his head fall back.
there's a BARK (O.S.)
Hear that?
What?
Now a DEEP RUMBLING (O.S.) can just be heard -- punctuate another sharp BARK (O.S.)
Ssh!
They listen.  More RUMBLING.  DEFINITE BARKS NOW.
(excited) Zero?!
The sounds get louder, closer... The group revives.  The mayor sits up.  Before long...
comes an ecstatic Jack driving a jaunty, Christmasland SN MOBILE, heavily laden with Christmasland memorabilia.  A Zero loops-the-loop around his master.
Look!  It's Jack!
I'M BACK!
The Halloweenland citizens gape.
Where've you been?
I can't wait to tell all of you all about it! (to the Mayor) Mayor!  Call us a town meeting!
The Mayor's hearse glides through town, p.a. system blari
Town meeting!  Town meeting tonight!
The hearse passes the DESERTED GOTHIC MANSE. Out stream the Creatures, Corpses, and other Vampires.
As the hearse passes and the announcement is heard, the GRAVESTONES open.
The hearse threads through town past the EVIL SCIENTIST'S

Sally and the Evil Scientist are both asleep -- the Evil scientist snores, his head on the lab table beside the no bowl; Sally has fallen asleep on her way through the door hat on, arm half-way into the sleeve of her coat.
Town meeting!  Town meeting tonight!
Neither of them hears the announcement.  Neither of them Their deep sleep goes on undisturbed.
The town hall is a tilted Chautauqua meetinghouse.  We HE noise of the crowd inside and see a few Halloweenland lat hurry in.

Jack stands at a podium on a stage at the end of the big hall.  Set up beside him is a table piled high with (at t point) non-descripit objects. The murmuring crowd presses close to the stage.  Of cours and the Evil Scientist are absent. Jack holds up his hands for attention.
Listen everyone.  I want to tell you about where I've been!
He sings:

There were objects so peculiar They were not to be believed All around things to tantalize my brain. It's a world unlike anything I've ever seen And as hard as I try... I can't seem to describe Like a most improbable dream... But you must believe when I tell you this It's as real as my skull, and it does exist.
Turning to sort through the objects on the table, Jack sp
Here...  Let me show you.
The people press even closer.
Ohhhh....
Jack holds up a wrapped gift:
This is a thing called a present. The whole thing starts with a box...
-- A box? --        Is it steel? --                     Are there locks? -- Is it filled with a pox? --                          A pox! -- How delightful, a pox!
Jack interrupts their excited babbling:
If you please!!!
He sings on:
Just a box with bright colored paper And the whole thing topped with a bow.
-- A bow? --        But why? --                  How ugly! -- What's in it? --                What's in it?
That's the point of the thing, not to know!
-- It's a bat. --              Will it bend? -- It's a rat. --              Will it break? -- Perhaps it's the head that I found in the lake.
Listen now, you don't understand. That's not the point of Christmasland.
Jack shakes his finger at them:
Now, pay attention.
He takes a Christmas stocking off his display table and s again:
Now we pick up an oversized sock... And bang it like this on the wall.
The irrepressible crowd bubbles over again:
-- Oh yes, does it still have a foot? -- Let me see... --                Let me look... -- Is it rotted and covered with gook?
Jack is getting very frustrated:
Let me explain.
But to no avail...
-- Small toys? --             Do they bite? --                           Do they snap? -- Or perhaps they just spring out and Scare girls and boys.
The Mayor struts to the front of the audience.
What a splendid idea -- This Christmas sounds fun. Why I fully endorse it! Let's try it at once!
But doubt immediately overtakes the Mayor as Jack express exasperation with the way things are going...
Everyone, please, now not so fast. There's something here that you don't quite grasp.
Confident face evaporating, the Mayor skulks off. Jack looks down at the faces tipped up toward him -- in t expressions, puzzlement replaces eagerness.
(to himself) Well, I may as well give them what they want.
Jack picks up his song again -- the showman once more:

And the best, I must confess, I have saved for the last For the ruler of this Christmasland... Is a fearsome king with a deep mighty voice Least, that is what I've come to understand. And I've also heard it told That he's something to behold Like a lobster, huge and red... And sets out to slay with his raingear on, Carting bulging sacks with his big great arms... That is, so I've heard it said.
Listening to this, the people of Halloweenland are absolu spellbound, rapt, and quiet for a change.
And on a dark, cold night Under full moonlight He flies off into a fog Like a vulture in the sky... And they call him -- Sandy Claws.
At this conclusion, a delightful shudder runs through the audience.
OOOOH....
They erupt into giddy chatter. Jack watches them from the stage, then turns to his displ and begins gathering up his many Christmasland souvenirs.
(sings wistfully to himself) Well, at least they're excited, But they don't understand That special kind of feeling ... In Christmasland.
Jack shakes a Frosty the Snowman paper weight and dreamil watches the little snowflakes drift down.
Oh well....
Sighing, he packs his treasures.

Jack happily decorates his room with the Christmasland so -- He festoons the electric chair with boughs of holly an sprig of mistletoe atop the confining head cap. -- He tosses wreaths around the necks of the gargoyles th down from corners of the ceiling. -- He ties a red bow on Zero.

in bed, snuggled down, wearing a nightcap, his pile of Ch books beside him, Jack gazes critically around his room. over-bright with electric lights -- they're strung everyw they can be strung.  Tinsel sparkles glaringly. Lips pursed, Jack climbs out of bed to pull a string of l out behind an obscuring cobweb, then isn't satisfied just them, but traces the intricate pattern of the cobweb with He steps back for perspective, comes forward to make an adjustment, steps back to look again...  He frowns.  He s his head.
It's not quite right; something's wrong... But what?...
He paces and looks, paces and looks -- but the mystery re mystery.
Still suffering the effects of her own sleeping potion, a disheveled Sally drags through the house. The DOORBELL RINGS (O.S.). Sally turns sluggishly.
(slowly) Who could that be?
She shuffles toward it.

head_text.subj: INT. EVIL SCIENTIST'S FRONT DOOR. DAY/MOMENTS LATER.

text: Sally drags open the front door.  There, on the front sto her utter astonishment stands JACK. He has on a cheery face, but it is obvious to her that he disturbed.
Good morning.
(voice little) Y-you don't have to say that. You don't need to pretend.  Not with me.
He looks quizzically at her.
Is the doctor in?
(calls) Who is it, Sally?
Answering for her, Jack strides right in:
(calls to the doctor) It's Jack Skellington.
(calls) Jack!  What a surprise, my boy, a rare pleasure indeed.  Come on back... I'm in the laboratory.
Jack heads back.  Sally looks tragically after.

Jack intently sets up a make-shift laboratory with equipm borrowed from the Evil Scientist -- a microscope, mortar pestle, petri dishes, a centrifuge, test tubes, beakers a filled with steaming liquid.
As Sally shuffles timidly into the room, the scientist do look up from his reading.
(blurts) Jack Skellington was here this morning.
The scientist nods without looking up:
Uh-huh.
He stayed a long time.
The scientist nods again.
When he left, he took a lot of equipment with him.
He's conducting experiments of his own.
Experiments?
Suddenly afraid for Jack, Sally wheels around and stumble
and UP THE RICKETY STAIRS.

Sally rushes in and hurries across to her window.  She st tip-toe and strains to peer out.  In the distance, betwee other buildings, she can just MAKE OUT A CORNER OF JACK'S TOWER. A strange glow emanates from there. Sally stares for a long time, biting her lip with worry, decisively: Sally turns to her desk.  She takes out a piece of paper pen and writes, reading aloud as she goes:

Dear Doctor...  Please don't come after me again.  Please let me go this time.  I am all grown up and need to find my own life now.  I hope you will understand, some day at least. Signed -- Sally.  P.S. I'll come visit very soon.  P.P.S. There's fresh soup in the 'fridge.  P.P.P.S. It isn't spiked.

She adds some x's and o's to the bottom of the letter, th it on the pillow of her bed where the doctor will be sure it. She takes a needle and spool of thread out of her drawer, them into her dress, then without warning,
with suicidal abandon.

Sally lands on the street outside -- sprawled, torn apart stuffing flowing out, stitches burst. In a moment, she flops upright.  She pulls out the needle thread, threads the needle and, glancing every so often o shoulder at the Evil Scientist's house, hurriedly proceed herself back together again. The job done.  She stashes the needle and thread and wobb stitches are looser than the doctor's) gets to her feet t only she's sewed one of her legs on backwards -- so that takes a step, her legs walk in opposite directions and sh right over. She lets out a little moan of frustration.  Swivelling, s back at the house, afraid of getting caught... She works even faster now, ripping out the stitches on th she replaced backwards and basting it back on facing forw These stitches are really huge and ungainly.  Still, they substantial enough to allow her to get to her feet and to away, though limping rather badly.

Jack has worked through the night and continues to work, concentrated, intent, doing his methodical best to study Christmas. -- He stares at an image of Sandy Claws he's drawn on the chalkboard -- with giant red lobster hand and elaborate raingear -- then erases it. -- He leafs back and forth through the Christmas books, e often stopping briefly on an image -- RUDOLF, THE RED-NOS

head_text.subj: REINDEER OR FROSTY, THE SNOWMAN OR AN ANNOTATED ILLUSTRAT
"THE STOCKINGS ARE HUNG BY THE CHIMNEY WITH CARE."

text: -- He scrapes a little bit of the shininess off a Christm ball.  With a mortar and pestle, he grinds the flake of s to a sparkling powder, then sprinkles the powder over him if it were fairy dust.  He strikes a pose and waits -- bu transformation occurs.  In another beat, he turns back to work table, freshly determined.
Sooner or later this Christmas will yield up its secrets to me.  I'll crack it!  I will!
-- He studies a strand of tinsel under the microscope.  I reflects his own hollow eye socket back to him.

Hiding in the shadows of the building across the street, stares up at Jack's room. She pulls back out of sight once -- when the Evil Scienti passes, obviously looking for her -- but steps out again as he's gone. Other citizens of Halloween look up at Jack's windows as pass and shake their heads with concern, but only Sally k vigil.

Jack stands at the chalkboard where he's scribbled elabor formulae: Good Cheer + Roasting Chestnuts + Sandy Claws = Christmas Fun.  Sugar Plums + Christmas trees + Rudolf, t Nosed Reindeer = Christas Fun.  Presents + Mistletoe + Sn = Christmas Fun.  If A = B and B = C and A = C, then what
He feverishly crosses out some phrases, corrects others, substitutes, modifies.
Using a pulley, Sally surreptitiously hoists up a basket

now chugs along tracks laid around the perimeter of Jack' Puffing smoke, it hauls a string of open cars filled with Christmas dolls and toys.  Jack adds more toys as the tin cars pass him. He looks up at the ODD SCRAPING SOUND of Sally's food bas knocking against the window.
he unhooks the basket and lifts it in.  Inside is dinner, lovingly wrapped in a napkin -- a skeleton chicken, a cou apple cores, and a cold bottle of newt juice. Jack leans
to see who sent this to him.  His gaze locks with Sally's below.  A beat.  He nods his thanks.  She waves -- slowly tragic sympathy.  He pulls back into his tower.
Sally keeps staring faithfully up at Jack's window.
Jack dances around a Christmas tree, giddily tossing on decorations.
Sally is back at her post across the street, watching
where a TALL CANDLE BURNS. AS IF IN TIME-LAPSE, the candle burns all the way down wh
Sally sleeps curled in the doorway across the street.  Sh to
gathering beneath Jack's window.
(quietly sing)
Something's up with Jack, something's up with Jack... A THIRD VAMPIRE adds his voice...
Don't know if we're ever going to get him back. Flanked by two corpses, a SLATHERING BEAST lumbers up, si
He's all alone up there, locked away inside... The CORPSE on his right joins in...
Never says a word... Then BOTH CORPSES and the beast sing...
... hope he hasn't died...
Then the whole crowd sings...
Something's up with Jack... ... Something's up with Jack... ... Something's up with Jack...
Sally stays back, separate from the crowd, silent.
Jack stands in the center of his room, a demon possessed, surrounded by Christmas mayhem -- the glittery decoration toys and books strewn all about him. He sings:

Christmastime is buzzing in my skull. Will it let me be?  I cannot tell. There're so many things I cannot grasp... When I think I've got it, then at last Through my bony fingers it does slip Like a snowflake in a fiery grip. Something's here I'm not quite getting Though I try, I keep forgetting Like a memory long since past Here in an instant, gone in a flash... What does it mean?  What does it mean? In these little bric-a-brac, A secret waiting to be cracked. These dolls and toys confuse me so... Confound it all -- I love it though! Simple objects nothing more But something's hidden through the door. Though I do not have the key, Something's there I cannot see. What does it mean?  What does it mean? I've read these Christmas books so many times I know the stories and I know the rhymes I know the Christmas carols all by heart... My skull's so full, it's tearing me apart. As often as I read them, something's wrong... So hard to put my bony finger on...
A thought strikes Jack.  He takes a new tack...  He whirl around, singing...

Or perhaps it's really not as Deep as I've been led to think. Am I trying much too hard...? Of course!  I've been too close to see! The answer's right in front of me! It's simple really, very clear, Like music drifting in the air Invisible but everywhere. Just because I cannot see it Doesn't mean I can't believe it.
Enthusiasm takes the place of torment.  Joy lightens Jack tortured soul.

You know I think this Christmas thing -- It's not as tricky as it seems. And why should they have all the fun? It should belong to anyone... Not anyone, in fact, but me! Why, I could make a Christmas tree. And there's no reason I can find That I couldn't handle Christmastime. I bet I could improve it too! And that's exactly what I'll do!
Jack hurries to the window and throws it open.
(shouts out) EUREKA!
the crowd is relieved.
Ahhh....
They smile up at their beloved Skeleton Jack.  All except Sally.
(sadly to herself) Oh Jack...  Now what fever has engulfed you?  Your poor sensitive mind...
Sally stares up at him...

A LINE of waiting Halloweeners extends out the entrance d The word, 'Christmas,' buzzes in the air. Sally stands in line with everyone else -- somewhere near back, just behind the members of the Street Band.  She pr what she's going to say to Jack when it's her turn --
(whispers almost inaudibly to herself) Jack, you must let go of this insanity.  Don't make this mistake.  Taking over Christmas is no way to fill the gaping hole you feel inside.
Sally cowers as she hears the Mayor call:
DR. FINKELSTEIN TO THE FRONT OF THE LINE!  DR. FINKELSTEIN, STEP RIGHT INSIDE!
Sally ducks out of sight behind the FURRY BEHEMOTH in bac as the
hobbles by.  Looking for Sally, he peers through his pinc the faces he passes.
(shouts again) DR. FINKELSTEIN!  WE'RE LOOKING FOR DR. FINKELSTEIN!
The Evil Scientist hobbles through the front door.

At the end of the hall is Jack. To one side of him is his Christmas treasure trunk filled brim with dolls and toys and decorations. On the other side, the Mayor sits at a table.  Before him open scroll -- a long list.  With his raven feather pen, Mayor enthusiastically marks off items and occasionally s notes: forging ahead with the making of Christmas, he and are giving out assignments to the citizens of Halloweenla At the moment, Jack discusses dollmaking with a COUPLE OF VAMPIRES...  One of the vampires cradles an example of a in the palm of his hand.  As he rocks it, its eyes close lying down, but open when it's brought upright.  The doll cries -- bleating sadly. The Vampires make a face at one another.
What kind of noise is that for a baby to make?
The other vampire shrugs.
Can you handle it?
We can improve it too.
I knew it!
The Vampires scurry off, still studying the babydoll -- l for other improvements. Jack turns to the Evil Scientist.
Doctor -- just the man I wanted to see.
Jack pulls a book out of his trunk.  He leafs through it PICTURE OF SANTA'S REINDEER hooked up to the sleigh and s Evil Scientist.
I need some of these.
The Evil Scientist peers closely at the picture of the re in Jack's book, making quick calculations.
These...?  Their construction should be very simple, I think.
bellows again, practically in the Evil Scientist's ear.
DR. FINKELSTEIN!
(snaps) Right here.
The Mayor glares at him resentfully.
It's about time.

The Mayor makes a big show of checking off the doctor's n Next, three mischievous Trick Or Treaters scuttle up to t Mayor's table.  They are small but insidious.  Profession Their names are LOCK, SHOCK & BARREL.
We're here!  You sent for us!
Specifically.
By name.
Lock.
Shock.
Barrel.
The Mayor announces the little Trick Or Treaters:
Oogie Boogie's Boys to see you, Jack!
Excellent.
The Evil Scientist shuffles off with the book. The Mayor studies his list again:
What a smashing success our Christmas will be!
Jack waves Lock, Shock & Barrel over...
I have a very important, very delicate job for you.
They come close and huddle before him.  Jack whispers his they titter, half-whispering themselves.
The three little Trick Or Treaters tip-toe out, still tit and whispering.  They sing:
Kidnap Mr. Sandy Claws...?
I wanna do it...
... Let's draw straws.
Jack said we should work together.
Three of a kind...
... Birds of a feather.
Now and forever...
... Weeee!
They scoot out of sight around a corner.
Lock, Shock & Barrel head toward their digs out of town.
Kidnap the Sandy Claws, Lock him up real tight Throw away the key and then Turn off all the lights.
First we're going to set some bait Inside a nasty trap and wait. When he comes a-sniffing we will Snap the trap and close the gate.
Wait!  I've got a better plan To catch this big red lobster man. Let's pop him in a boiling pot And when he's done we'll butter him up!
Lock, Shock & Barrel arrive at the ominous stinking place
Kidnap the Sandy Claws Throw him in a box Bury him for ninety years And then see if he talks.
Then Mr. Oogie Boogie Man Can take the whole thing over then. He'll be so pleased I do declare That he will cook him rare...
They zip down the cellar stairs.
Weeee!
The dank, crumbling stairs lead to...
Once in their corner of the dungeon, the little Trick Or start to gather the things they'll need to do their job.
I say that we take a cannon Aim it at his door and then Knock three times and when he answers Sandy Claws will be no more.
You're so stupid, think now -- If we blow him up to smithereens, We may lose some pieces and then Jack will beat us black and green.
Kidnap the Sandy Claws Tie him in a bag Throw him in the ocean And then see if he is sad.
There is a bone-chilling stirring in the next room.  All the little Trick or Treaters react.  As one, they shoot o the corner furthest away from the sounds and lower their
Because Mr. Oogie Boogie Is the meanest guy around, If I were on his Boogie list, I'd get out of town.
He'll be so pleased by our success That he'll reward us too I bet. Perhaps he'll make his special brew Of snake and spider stew...
MMMMMMM...!
We're his little henchman And we take our job with pride.
We do our best to please him, And stay on his good side.
I wish my cohorts weren't so dumb.
I'm not the dumb one...
Shut up and listen...!
The other two stop...
I've got something, listen now, This one is real good, you'll see. We'll send a present to his door Upon there'll be a note to read.
Now in the box, we'll wait and hide Until his curiosity Entices him to look inside...
And then we'll have him, one, two, three!
Fully exuberant again, they gleefully collect their last necessities.
Kidnap the Sandy Claws, Beat him with a stick. Lock him up for ninety years And see what makes him tick.
They head back up their cellar steps.
The three Trick or Treaters race through a deserted lot.
Kidnap the Sandy Claws, Tie him in a knot Put him in a coffin, How we'd like to see him rot.
Lock, Shock & Barrel skip among the tombstones.
Kidnap the Sandy Claws. Chop him into bits Mr. Oogie Boogie is Sure to get his kicks.
Lock, Shock & Barrel head for the forest that Jack wander through.
Kidnap the Sandy Claws. See what we will see, Lock him in a cage And then throwaway the key.

They reach the very edge forest -- they are still in the one step ahead, it is dark and gloomy. Lock, the natural-born leader of the three, stops in his in the last possible light.  The other two bump into him, succession.  Then all three crouch down at once.  Beat. Simultaneously giggling, they suddenly streak forward int woods and, in a moment, are swallowed up into the PITCH-BLACK. The only evidence of them left is the sound of their gigg The giggles recede, then fade...
No part of the line stands outside now.  The few citizens still waiting for assignments stand...
A very anxious Sally stands at the head of the line, in a going over and over what she intends to say:
(almost inaudibly) Jack, you must let go of this insanity...  This is a mistake...
Behind her the Furry Behemoth waits patiently.
works with the Street Band.  Demonstrating, he shakes a h piece studded with sleigh bells.  The bells jingle cheerf
Okay.  Now you.
The members of the Band rattle their bones in response -- legs and arms, echoing the jingle of the bells, but with own distinctive hollow CLANK. Jack laughs, enormously pleased.
Perfect!...  Now let's try this...
Using various jingling bells, Jack shakes out the tune to Bells." The Band clanks the tune right back -- phrase for phrase.
watches with an increasing sense of doom as her turn with nears. Jack heartily shakes hands and back-slaps the three membe the street band.  They head off practicing...
(calls after) Thanks!  You're the absolute best!
He turns to Sally -- who stands frozen, wide-eyed, her he wild bird trapped in the cage of her chest.  He smiles encouragingly at her.
Hi.  I've saved a really special job for you.
He gestures for her to step closer. Stiffly, she does.
(confidentially) I want you to be the one who makes my Sandy Claws outfit.
She looks stunned.  Jack nods eagerly and pats her, mista silence for awe at the responsibility.
I know you can do it.
He enthusiastically proceeds to describe the costume:

It's bright red, the reddest red you can imagine -- both the jacket and the pair of pants... The boots are black.  There's a big black belt that goes around the middle...  Oh, and there's white trim on the cuffs and collar.
Swallowing hard, Sally looks up at him, her wide eyes moi voice is tiny.
Are you sure, Jack?
Jack suddenly looks confused.  He stops mid-gesture --
Am I sure?
Brow furrowing, he stares at the ceiling and thinks. Sally holds her breath, hoping... Finally, Jack shrugs.
Well... the trim is traditionally white from everything I've studied, but if you think green would give it more dash...  I trust your judgement.  I know you'll do a great job.  Whatever you decide!
Lock, Shock and Barrel race in dragging behind them a big with something squirming inside!
Jack!  Jack!  We caught him! We've got him!
strides excitedly to meet them, leaving Sally.

flees, mortified, miserable.  She had hoped to help Jack, spare him the pain of his enterprise, to save him from hi Floppy and weak (her legs lost some stuffing in her jump Evil Scientist's window), she runs as best she can, arms pinwheeling...
in a frenzy of giggling, open the big sack and who should out but the EASTER BUNNY. Jack's face drops.  He turns on the three Trick Or Treate
(loud) That's not Sandy Claws!
It isn't?
Who is it then?
(louder) Not Sandy Claws!
The three shrink back.
We followed your instructions.
We went through the door...
...In the tree.
Which door!?
The door.
WELL, TAKE HIM BACK!
Jack turns to the Easter Bunny and speaks loudly and slow him, hoping to be understood.
I'm very sorry for the inconvenience, sir.
He scowls at the three Trick Or Treaters.
Shall I send somebody else for Sandy Claws?
No!
Not at all!
We can handle it.
We'll get it right this time --
-- for sure!
I told you -- there's more than one door!  Sandy Claws is behind the door shaped like this --
He holds up a cut-out of a Christmas tree.
Got it!
They stuff the Easter Bunny back into the sack and hurry
(shouts after them) Take him home first.  And apologize again.  Be careful with Sandy Claws when you catch him!  Treat him nicely!
They scurry out the double doors.
Sally sits at a sewing machine, abjectly stitching Jack's Claus suit.  Finished with a long seam, she holds up the see how it's coming along... and shudders in its cheerful red glare.
If only he would come back to his senses...
Shaking her head, she sets the suit back in place to stit another seam. But Sally is alone in her distress.  Beyond her -- the li Halloween factory gladly hums along making Christmas.

Jack supervises and approves as the residents of Hallowee busily manufacture the Halloween version of Christmas toy dolls, decorations, doing their well-intentioned best to the warmest, most magical Christmas yet. Santa's eyes go wide and he begins to sputter -- searchin the words that could conceivably express the depths of hi feelings. Sally looks on, horrified.

Consider this a vacation, Sandy, a reward.  You've worked hard for a long time.  It's your turn to take it easy. Leave everything to me... You're going to be so pleased. You just relax and enjoy yourself while you're here. (to Lock, Shock & Barrel) See that he's comfortable, boys...
Lock, Shock and Barrel grab ahold of Santa to drag him of but Jack stops them--

He pops Santa's cap on his own head.  It is too big and d charmingly over one of Jack's big eye sockets.  He grins biggest grin yet.

She rushes off.

Where?

gazes about her in happy wonder.  The sight of the fog br wide, welcoming look of hope to her face. She dumps out the tea -- it eats a hole in the ground -- won't be needing it after all...
swallows everyone.
I'll never get the sleigh off the ground in this.  The reindeer can't see an inch in front of their noses...
This fog's as thick as...
(finishes the thought) ...Jellied brains.
Yeah...

There is a thin ghostly bark (O.S.) -- it belongs to Zero little jack o'lantern nose floats in... a tiny beacon pen the fog.

After a long beat...

We HEAR the sounds of RUMMAGING, of Jack MUTTERING:
Where did I put that book...? I know it's in here somewhere...  Here it is...
We HEAR pages turned back and forth...  Then with charact melodramatic flourish Jack RECITES:

Barking, Zero swoops with pure joy. The crowd cheers. Zero floats to the front of the sleigh and takes position jack o'lantern nose glows brighter and brighter, soon illuminating the whole sleigh.  Jack leaps aboard.
We're off!
With a crack of his skeleton whip, Jack and his ghostly e are instantly aloft.  In a moment, they are gone...
gapes into the swirling fog.  She stares miserably into t she emptied, then back up into the fog-choked sky.

(voice weak) I thought I could be Santa.  I thought I could be better than Santa.  And what did I do instead?  Instead I killed Christmas.

Crumpling, Jack weeps.  Zero, ever faithful, makes himsel hankie and wipes Jack's wet eyes. >>>>> JACK'S SADDEST OF SAD SONGS. Jack sings as if his heart had broken in two.  He is at h lowest of lows.  Yet, being Jack, being irrepressibly buo the end of the song, he has completely worked himself bac from grief very nearly to exuberance -- he must save Sant must restore Christmas as it should be! He opens a tombstone, lifting it up as easily as if it we door to a storm cellar and, filled with determination, ru down toward Halloweenland.

text: Santa and Sally dangle perilously above a PIT.  They've b bound and gagged and they writhe in terror. From the murky depths below, SKELETON CROCODILES leap up jaws snapping hungrily.  Watching, Oogie Boogie snickers. lowers Santa and Sally closer.
Scrawny ol' things -- they haven't eaten in centuries. I'd say it's about time we put some meat on their bones, don't you?
Suddenly, there's a
behind him -- the crash of the door being kicked in. And there stands JACK.
I should say so.
Jack sweeps Boogie off his feet and holds him above the p himself.  Immediately, the terrorizer is terrified.

Jack!  How great to see you. We were all worried about you. I was just giving our guests here a... a tour of the place. I told them it was dangerous, but they insisted on a closer look.  What could I do?
He smiles sheepishly.
How about the whole show?

He dumps Oogie Boogie over the edge, but delicately keeps of a choice thread. AS HE FALLS, OOGIE BOOGIE UNRAVELS COMPLETELY. His insides escape into the dark -- with the sounds of wi flapping and feet skittering -- and, IN THE END, ALL THAT OF HIS SHAPELESS SACK OF A BODY IS ONE LONG THREAD. In the pit below, the crocodile skeletons scoot around, j clapping, having themselves a feast.
Jack finishes untying Santa and Sally.  He works quickly. ungags Sally.
(with glad relief) We heard you'd been pulverized to bone dust.
For what I did, I deserve to be bone dust.
Jack looks away from Santa's angry gaze.  He takes off Sa cap and replaces it on Santa's head...
This is where it belongs...  I was only trying to do a good job, but I made a real mess of everything.  I'm sorry.
Cringing, he unties Santa's gag.  Santa scowls and straig his cap but, rather than chastise Jack, immediately makes door.
No time to talk now...  I've got to go fix Christmas!
Santa charges off.
Various townspeople duck out of the way to avoid Jack -- stopped to gaze up into the empty night sky.  Zero floats him.
I hope it's not too late for him to set Christmas right.
Jack sighs and drags himself up the deserted street.
Well, Zero... I guess it's just you and me... (the thought dawns) ...And Sally.  She sure stuck by us, didn't she?
Downcast as he stalks along, Jack doesn't notice when it to SNOW. At first, just a few sparkling flakes fall.
Look!
What is it?
It snows more and more.
White thing's...
Everywhere...
Could it be --
(finishes the thought) -- SNOW??
Zero barks excitedly.  Jack finally looks up.
(with wonder) It is snow...  But how?
As if in answer to Jack's question we HEAR
high up in the sky. A SLOW SMILE SPREADS ACROSS JACK'S FACE. The residents of Halloween come out to experience the sno this miracle of Christmas that has come to Halloween.
Jack joins in the celebration -- but seems always to be l around for someone.
As the celebrating goes on in town below, Sally climbs Ce Hill.  Sitting down at the top, she looks out at the roun which shines behind the curtain of falling snow.  She is sing a brief reprise of
Soon, A SECOND VOICE joins in, making the song a DUET.  T second voice belongs to JACK. He has found Sally. Jack sings:
My dearest friend, if you don't mind I'd like to join you by your side Let's sit together, you and I Alone, where we can watch the sky.
He sits beside her.  Together they look out at the moon a snow.

Above the CLOUDS and the SNOW, past SANTA flying into the distance aboard his sleigh, above the gleaming light of t Christmas MOON, and into the NIGHT, pulling BACK AND BACK THE STARS... Santa's voice returns to narrate:

And finally, everything worked out just fine -- Christmas was saved, though there wasn't much time. But, after that night, things were never the same, Each holiday now knew the other one's name. And so when their long isolation had ended, They cautiously reached out, and slowly befriended. And each shared a bit of the things that they had With each other, and found out it wasn't so bad -- They had snowflakes in Halloween, those we could spare, And we here in Christmas enjoyed a few scares. The fireworks gave the Easter Bunnies a thrill And St. Patrick's Day cherishes Easter Eggs still. And though that one Christmas, things got out of hand, I'm still rather fond of that skeleton man. Though misguided I think his intentions were good. He was just a poor skeleton misunderstood. So many years later I thought I'd drop in, And there was old Jack, still looking quite thin. With four or five skeleton children at hand Playing strange little tunes in their xylophone band. And I asked old Jack, 'Do you remember the night, When the sky was so dark, and the moon shone so bright? 'When a million small children pretending to sleep Nearly didn't have Christmas at all, so to speak? 'And would, if you could, turn that mighty clock back To that long fateful night?  Now, think carefully, Jack. 'Would you do the whole thing all over again? Knowing what you know now, knowing what you knew then?' And he smiled like the old Pumpkin King that I knew, Then turned, and asked softly of me... 'Wouldn't you?'
